did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: USS Arizona Collection, 1907-2015 (bulk 1915-1941)
did.abstract: This collection contains papers, photographs, objects, and memorabilia of the USS Arizona from its christening in 1915 to destruction on December 7, 1941. Also held within the collection are materials documenting the annual memorial ceremonies held at the University of Arizona Student Union and the papers of the USS Arizona Reunion Association.

repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

prefercite.p: USS Arizona Collection (AZ 517). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The USS Arizona (BB-39) was launched by the United States Navy on June 19, 1915 and later commissioned on October 17, 1916. The ship was the second and last ship of the Pennsylvania class of super dreadnought battleships and boasted a 608 foot long hull made of steel which at its maximum breath reached 97 feet. She remained in the United States during World War I and instead served as a gunnery training ship on Chesapeake Bay. Following the end of World War I, she departed for Britain. On December 12, 1918 the ship sailed from Portsmouth, England acting as escort for President Woodrow Wilson to the Paris Peace Conference in Brest, France. In early 1919 the US Navy sent the ship to the Mediterranean on a few months' cruise. In 1921 the ship was sent into the Pacific to join the United States Pacific Fleet. From 1929-1931, the ship was modernized and used for training exercises between the two World Wars. The USS Arizona was used as aid to survivors of the Long Beach, CA earthquake of 1933. By 1940, the ship was a part of the Pacific Fleet that was transferred from California to Pearl Harbor, HI to deter imperialist Japanese forces. It was while stationed here that the USS Arizona was bombed during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, which resulted in the death of 1,177 officers and crewmen and the sinking of the ship. The wreckage of the ship is at the bottom of Pearl Harbor and the USS Arizona Memorial, dedicated on May 30, 1962, straddles the ship's hull.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into six series.

list.item: Subseries 2: USS Arizona and Personnel Photographs, 1916-1940
Series V: USS Arizona Reunion Association, Crew-Kin and Related Materials, 1931-2015

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This is an artificial collection comprised of materials gifted by various donors. The collection contains materials documenting the USS Arizona from its christening in June 19, 1915 to destruction on December 7, 1941. Also included are materials that document annual memorial ceremonies held at the University of Arizona Student Union and the papers of the USS Arizona Reunion Association.

The collection is comprised of six series. The first series has four subseries and comprises the bulk of the collection. This series contains photographic materials taken by the ship's personnel, the United States Navy, and other entities that document the history of the ship during its lifespan. Materials document the ship's crew, its arsenal and machinery, the various locales where the ship was stationed or provided aid, as well as other US Navy ships. Also included are materials that document the ship's interior and exterior, the December 7, 1941 Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, and the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.

The second series contains documents that detail the history of the ship and the lives of her crew as well as materials documenting the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Materials within this series include books; programs for sporting events, religous services, and other activities on board ship; cards; invitations; certificates; ship logs; crew rosters; listings of crew and personnel; as well as USS Arizona Memorial materials; and copies of the At Em' Arizona newsletter and other materials that were generated during the ship's lifespan. Also contained in this series are scrapbooks by various sailors who served on the ship. These scrapbooks date from the 1929-1955 and contain black and white photographs, documents, and ephemera that detail the history of the USS Arizona and other US Navy battleships and the United States involvement in World War II.

The third series contains objects that resided on the ship as well as memorial and commemorative objects. The fourth series contains audio visual materials and is comprised of cassette tapes of oral histories with sailors who served on the USS Arizona as well as VHS tapes of USS Arizona memorial ceremonies.

The fifth series has seven subseries and consists of materials created by the USS Arizona Reunion Association and USS Arizona Crew-Kin Association, which are comprised of individuals who served on the USS Arizona and their kin. The sixth series contains appendices which hold access copies of documents and photographs held within the collection.

relatedmaterial.p: Some Materials from this collection are on permanent exhibit as part of the USS Arizona Exhibit located at the University of Arizona Student Union Memorial Center.
For more information, see Digital Exhibit.

For more photographs of the USS Arizona, see collections held at the U.S. Naval Institute, USS Arizona Memorial Collection held by the National Park Service, the National Archives, and the Naval Historical Center, NH.

did.unittitle: Series 1: Photographic Materials,

scopecontent.p: This series has four subseries and comprises the bulk of the collection and contains photographic materials taken by the ship's personnel and the United States Navy that document the crew of the ship, the daily lives and duties of sailors who served on the ship, interior and exterior views of the ship and its armament, and the various locales where the ship was stationed, held port, or provided aid. Also included in this series are materials that document the Neptune’s Court Ceremony, the 1934 filming of the motion picture Here Comes the Navy featuring James Cagney and Gloria Stewart, and the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii on December 7, 1941. Certain materials are copies of original photographs held at the National Archives, The National Park Service USS Arizona Memorial, the Naval Historical Center, NH, the U.S. Naval Institute, and other collections. The majority of the materials are undated, but are believed to date circa 1920-1941. Item titles contain an accession number assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

did.unittitle: Subseries 1: Negatives,

scopecontent.p: This subseries is arranged numerically by accession number and is described at the item level. It contains copy negatives of photographs held within the collection. Item titles contain an accession number assigned by the Arizona State Museum upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

did.unittitle: 1918 USS Arizona Crew, 85-1-1,
Subseries 2: USS Arizona and Personnel Photographs,

scopecontent.p: This subseries comprises the bulk of this series and is arranged numerically by accession number. Items within this subseries are described at the item level. Certain materials are duplicated in other series within the collection. Materials consist primarily of black and white photographs of varying size that document the interior and exterior of the ship, its armament and machinery, the USS Arizona and other US Navy battleships stationed at various ports, the ship and her crew engaging in training exercises on the ship and on base, the ship in dry dock at various ports, and other scenarios. Materials within this subseries also document the crew and individual sailors engaging in routine duties as well as personal activities while on ship leave. Materials of particular interest from this subseries document the 1933 Long Beach, California earthquake relief efforts, the ship sailing the Panama Canal, the Neptune's Court Ceremony, the 1934 filming of Here Comes the Navy featuring James Cagney and Gloria Stewart, various USS Arizona athletic teams, and the December 7, 1941 Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Undated materials are believed to date circa 1920-1941. Item titles contain a three digit accession number assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

Subseries 3: 8x10 Photographs,

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains 8x10 black and white photographs and is arranged numerically by accession number. Materials are described at the item level. Materials document the ship at various locales, interior and exterior views of the ship, and various onboard weaponry and arsenal. This subseries also contains materials that document crew engaging in daily duties and personal activities, the ship at the Panama Canal in 1931, and the USS Arizona Memorial at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. A portion of the materials document the December 7, 1941 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii and the bombing of the USS Arizona in particular. Certain materials are duplicated in other series within the collection. Item titles contain a three digit accession number assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

Subseries 4: Oversize Photographic Material,

scopecontent.p: This subseries is described at the item level. It contains oversize copy negatives and prints that document the ship and her crew in various locales, the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, as well as the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Materials of particular note held within this subseries include the christening and launching of the ship on 19 June 1915, and the ship's visit to Guantanamo Bay, Cuba circa 1920. This subseries also contains materials created by Carlos W. Cecil who served on the USS Arizona from 1918-1920. The materials are comprised of mounted black and white photographs with accompanying text and documents which include the 1918 May 16 – 1920 May 20 cruising records of the USS Arizona and USS Nevada. Certain materials are duplicated in other series within the collection. Item titles contain a three digit accession number assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

did.unittitle: Series 2: Documents and Scrapbooks,

scopecontent.p: This series contains documents that detail the history of the ship and the lives of her crew as well as materials documenting the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Materials within this series include books, a Continuous Service Certificate dating from 1941 issued to Andrew Jackson Bowen, a notebook from 1939 belonging to William D. Osborne, programs for sporting events, religous services, and other activities on board ship, cards, invitations, certificates, ship logs, crew rosters, listings of crew and personnel, USS Arizona Memorial materials including an architectural deck plan held in box 42, newspapers, magazines, sheet music, and copies of the At Em' Arizona newsletter and other materials that were generated during the ship's lifespan. Also included within this series are scrapbooks by various sailors and Marines who served on the ship. These scrapbooks contain materials that date from around the 1920s-1930s and contain newspaper and magazine articles, black and white photographs, documents, and ephemera. Item poses a three digit accession number written on the verso, which was assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

Series 3: Objects,

scopecontent.p: This series contains three dimensional objects as well as memorial and commemorative objects. Item titles contain a three digit accession number assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction. Some of the materials within this series are on permanent exhibit as part of the USS Arizona Exhibit located at the University of Arizona Student Union Memorial Center.

Series 4: Audio Visual Materials,

scopecontent.p: This series contains audio visual materials and is comprised of cassette tapes of oral histories of sailors who served on the USS Arizona as well as VHS tapes of USS Arizona memorial ceremonies. Item titles contain a three digit accession number assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

Series 5: USS Arizona Reunion Association, Crew-Kin and Related Materials,

scopecontent.p: This series has seven subseries and consists of materials created by the USS Arizona Reunion Association and USS Arizona Crew-Kin Association, an association comprised of individuals who served on the USS Arizona and their kin.

did.unittitle: Subseries 1: Documents,

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains documents including ship rosters, and books and other printed materials related to the history of the USS Arizona and the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Box 49, folder 5 contains a recounting of December 7, 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor by William D. Osborne Jr.

Subseries 2: Photographs,

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographic materials created by Cline E. Herrin, Roy Hubert, and Joe Vivirito who served as crew members aboard the USS Arizona. These materials document interior and exterior views of the ship, its armament and machinery, crew and personnel engaging in daily activities and duties, US Navy ships, and the Neptune's Court Ceremony. The subseries also contains USS Arizona Reunion Association reunion and ceremony materials. Item titles contain a three digit accession number assigned by the University of Arizona Student Union upon donation of the item. This number consists of a tripartite system that consists of three parts that refer to the year of the item’s acquisition, the transaction number of that year, and the individual specimen number within that transaction.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous USS Arizona Photographs,

scopecontent.p: Folder contains materials that document exterior views of the ship, aircraft, the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, HI, and sailors. Folder also contains a photograph of the USS Arizona at sea in Smyrna, Turkey in 1919.

did.unittitle: Cline E. Herrin Photographs,

scopecontent.p: Folder contains materials that document the Neptunus Rex Ceremony, the ship docked at Bremerton, Washington, interior and exterior views of the ship, its armament, 1937 observation aircraft crash, the ship's crew, ship competitions, and the 1939 USS Arizona Rifle Team.

did.unittitle: Roy Hubert Photographs,

scopecontent.p: Folder contains materials that document the ship at the San Francisco Bay Bridge, the 1931 crew, The USS Arizona in the Norfolk, Virginia Bay, 1931, The 1931 USS Arizona Football Team, the 1933-1934 USS Arizona Basketball Team, and the 1932 Champion Boat Crew.

did.unittitle: Joe Vivirito Photographs,

scopecontent.p: Folder contains materials that document wrecked aircraft, exterior views of the ship, crew, armament, the Neptunus Rex Ceremony, US Navy Battleships, and The USS Arizona Docked at Long Beach California, 1938.

did.unittitle: Copies of Jim Vlach Photographs,

scopecontent.p: Folder contains photocopies of photographs from Jim Vlach's photo album. Materials depict Jim Vlach posing with friends and family and date 1942-1943. Folder also contains photocopies of photographs of Jim Vlach's 1996 visit to the USS Arizona Memorial.

Subseries 3: Oral History Transcriptions,

scopecontent.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically and contains transcriptions of oral histories conducted with men who served on the USS Arizona during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, December 7, 1941.

did.unittitle: Subseries 4: Correspondence,

scopecontent.p: This subseries is arranged chronologically and contains correspondence regarding administrative operations of the USS Arizona Reunion Association including the status of members, correspondence with media outlets, and other subjects pertaining to the USS Arizona and the USS Arizona Memorial in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.

Subseries 7: Lauren F. Bruner Materials,

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials relating to Lauren F. Bruner, a sailor on the USS Arizona who survived the Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. Subseries contains materials documenting his visit to the University of Arizona on 2013 December 5 as well as commemorative apparel donated by Lauren F. Bruner.
